The CDKN2A allele is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes p16, which inhibits cyclin-dependent kinases (CDK4/6). Loss of CDKN2A function leads to uncontrolled cell cycle progression. This allele is associated with several cancers, including **melanoma**, **pancreatic cancer**, and **sarcomas**. CDKN2A also interacts with MDM2 and TP53, which regulate the G1/S checkpoint. Loss of CDKN2A can lead to the activation of E2F transcription factors, promoting cell proliferation and contributing to tumorigenesis. Additionally, CDKN2A's loss can result in the inactivation of RB1, further promoting cell cycle progression. These effects make CDKN2A a key player in the development of **melanoma** and other cancers. 

\boxed{Melanoma}
